author: sky.cactus
content: Can anyone think of some arguments against having ERC20 transfer events for all ETH transfers in a transaction?  The only one I can think of is that it would increase the operational cost of attaching ETH to a transaction/call and people don't seem to like gas cost changes very much.  Are there other reasons it would be bad?

author: sky.cactus
content: Ideally, they would look just like token transfers and show up in the receipt logs (in proper order) right along side other events.  This way ETH would be treated the same as tokens when it comes to tracking them.

author: daniellehrner
content: Isn't that what WETH is for? I see that it might be useful for some use cases, but for a majority of transfers it might just be noise and nobody using it.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> Also, that would be mixing layers? ERC20 is just a standard implemented on top of the EVM, making the EVM emit events of the same type would be a little bit strange

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is no one wants to use just WETH because you need ETH for gas fees, so it is easier to just use ETH everywhere.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree, it is a bit of layer mixing.  A separate system for tracking ETH movement within a transaction could be done instead, though I think there is value in being able to identify the order of ETH movement relative to other events.

author: sky.cactus
content: I also wouldn't be opposed to the format of the logs being different from ERC20 logs.  The idea here is to have a log automatically generated every time ETH moves between accounts.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
would logs also be generated for "implicit" moves like validator withdrawals and block producer tips, or only inside "normal" txs?  if its only for normal txs, maybe this should only work under a new tx type?  My main rationale for a new tx type is that it ensures this is an opt-in change, as I can envision suddenly getting `transfer`-like events for ETH could break some processes.  Also a new tx type makes it very clear which txs would have these added to their receipts, otherwise it feels like there's more room for corner cases (e.g. what if tx A is first mined before the fork but then reorged out and into a different block _after_ the fork, would it now have these events when it didn't before, etc.).

anyways I definitely agree that _even if_ the log produced _happened_ to look like ERC20 `transfer` logs the EIP that proposes this should have its own format specified.  Also it might be worth getting the polygon/bor team's input, as IIRC they inject "implicit" events like this in their L2 (not transfer events, IIRC the events are more related to consensus changes) and I'm sure they have feedback on what did and didn't work well there.

author: sky.cactus
content: I was initially thinking only normal transactions, but I'm not opposed to the others.
